Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Reflective Practice for Graduate Engineering Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will implement e-portfolios for graduate student as a mechanism to research how reflective practice helps students develop their identities in their dual roles as teachers and researchers. The research study uses a mixed-methods approach at four different sites to answer questions on how reflective practice influences identity development. The research will be integrated with the educational activities of the PI and is informed by a strong evaluation plan.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to improve the future professoriate, who will in turn increase of the success of engineering students from all groups. One of the research sites includes a significant fraction of under-represented students. The results of the project will be disseminated through both workshops and education and electronic resources that will be freely distributed to other institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals achieved in this project included:

1) Developing and implementing curriculum to help graduate students construct professional portfolios in which they reflectively document their roles in research, education, service and lifelong learning. A curriculum was developed and implemented that helped engineering graduate students construct integrated professional identities in online portfolios, working at Virginia Tech and with 4 partner schools. Also, the original curriculum was expanded to include graduate students in non-STEM disciplines as well as students preparing for careers other than the professoriate. 

2) Developing and implementing a survey to measure the degree to which graduate students' experiences in school align with their professional goals. A quantitative survey was created, validated and implemented that successfully gauged relationships between graduate students' academic experiences and their professional goals. Quantitative analysis of surveys indicated that there are misalignments between graduate students' academic experiences and their professional goals, especially in their goals as professional educators.

3) Analyzing portfolios for integrative professional identity construction. The research team collected data from participants' ePortfolios, developed a qualitative coding schema, and analyzed this data to discover the extent to which participants used ePortfolios to construct integrated professional identities. This research was informed by theory relevant to reflective practice and self-authorship. Qualitative analysis showed that the process of creating an ePortfolio using our curriculum resulted in greater integration of professional identity, especially in relation to one's holistic identity, as well as increased awareness of one's representation of self to varied audiences.

Intellectual Merit:  The findings from this project impact the discipline of engineering education by contributing to the ongoing work of researchers in graduate studies, ePortfolios, writing in the disciplines, and reflective practice. The work builds on substantial work done at the undergraduate level that focuses on how engineering students construct professional identities that incorporate not only the structure of typical academic faculty roles, but also personal values. In addition, the findings indicate that work must be done to better align graduate program pedagogies and cultures with the realities of academic and non-academic work. This alignment is critical in preparing effective future faculty in engineering. 

This grant directly contributed to the professional development of 47 graduate students who participated in the initial pilot and subsequent adaptations of the Portfolio to Professoriate project. In addition, the grant funding provided training and professional development for one post-doc, Wende Garrison (2011-2013), and three graduate students, Rachel Kajfez (2011-2013), Martina Svyantek (2013-2015), and Chris Gewirtz (2016). 

The results have been shared via 8 peer-reviewed publications, 10 presentations, 2 workshops and an open access, free online curriculum. The curriculum and validated survey are freely available to the public.

Broader Impacts: The work of this project at other institutions has led to expansion beyond engineering to graduate students in all disciplines. For example, through work with Helen Chen and others at Stanford, the Portfolio to Professoriate project has contributed to a robust eportfolio culture that is available to all graduate students. Also, the continuous presentations at the conferences of the Association of Authentic, Experiential, and Evidence-Based Learning (AAEEBL) have reached audiences across all disciplines and levels.

Engagement in the ePortfolio practices developed in this project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas through structured yet student-owned methods of communicating with advisors during annual report meetings. It improved the attitudes of members of underrepresented groups in ways that could improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions by offering a process that helps them integrate their engineering professional identities holistically with their professional identities relating to teaching, service and lifelong learning. 

The eportfolio practices developed in this study also contributed to programs for student-level assessment and program evaluation at the graduate level and in the development of a liberal education program in innovation. The project included an implemented assessment plan for graduate programs employing a research-to-practice approach that promotes reflective practice and participant design. The plan uses the ePortfolio tool to simultaneously collect program assessment data, engage graduate students in reflective practice, and help students prepare professional portfolios that showcase their professional work as engineers and educators.

This project has expanded beyond science and technology graduate programs to include student participants in the humanities and fine arts. These students also experience disconnections between their experiences in graduate school as compared to their professional goals. Also, these students encounter similar benefits and challenges in reflectively recording their practices. This process of creating a professional narrative that is supported by evidential artifacts and designed to communicate to multiple audiences yields insights to the students on how to leverage their academic experiences and present their professional selves in the job market. These experiences recorded and analyzed as data reveal to researchers many of the perceptions and barriers that graduate students face.
